fields.value: Channeling Remittances to Education: A Field Experiment among Migrants from El Salvador

dsDescriptionValue.value: We implement a randomized experiment offering Salvadoran migrants matching funds for educational remittances, which are channeled directly to a beneficiary student in El Salvador chosen by the migrant. The matches lead to increased educational expenditures, higher private school attendance, and lower labor supply of youths in El Salvador households connected to migrant study participants. We find substantial "crowd-in" of educational investments: for each $1 received by beneficiaries, educational expenditures increase by $3.72. We find no shifting of expenditures away from other students, and no effect on remittances.

grantNumberAgency.value: University of Michigan Population Studies Center

fields.value: Research Support, Innovations for Poverty Action

value: Individuals and households in El Salvador with relatives in the Washington DC area who would have been eligible for secondary or tertiary studies in the 2012 school year.

fields.value: Fundación Empresarial para el Desarrollo Educativo (FEPADE)

Migrant participants were randomly assigned to be either part of a control group or one of three treatment groups that received offers for the EduRemesa at varying matching levels. All groups received a handout that discussed the importance of supporting education in El Salvador and suggested sending remittances directly to students in monthly installments, while the three treatment groups also received pamphelets informing them about EduRemesa. Treatment 1 group did not have to pay administrative fees. Treament 2 did not have to pay administrative fees as well as had a 1:1 match on every dollar sent as a part of the program. Treatment 3 was similar to Treatment 2 except they received a 3:1 match on ever dollar sent as a part of the program.
